facts: Cheese making dates back over 4,000 years, with evidence found in ancient Sumerian texts.
There are over 1,800 different types of cheese produced worldwide.
It takes approximately 10 pounds of milk to make 1 pound of cheese.
Cheddar cheese gets its characteristic orange color from added annatto, a natural food coloring.
The holes in Swiss cheese are caused by carbon dioxide bubbles during fermentation.
Mozzarella cheese originated in Italy and was traditionally made from water buffalo milk.
The most expensive cheese in the world is Pule, made from Serbian donkey milk, costing over $600 per pound.
Cheese contains casein protein, which releases opioid-like compounds during digestion.
Ancient Romans used cheese as currency and gave cheese rations to soldiers.
Blue cheese gets its distinctive veining from Penicillium mold cultures.
Parmesan cheese wheels are aged for a minimum of 12 months, with some aged over 36 months.
The largest cheese ever made weighed 57,518 pounds and was created in Wisconsin.
Cheese is one of the most nutrient-dense foods, containing protein, calcium, and vitamins.
The United States is the world's largest producer of cheese, making over 12 billion pounds annually.
Cheese caves in places like Roquefort, France, provide ideal conditions for aging cheese.
Rennet, an enzyme used in cheese making, was traditionally sourced from calf stomach lining.
Fresh cheeses like ricotta and cottage cheese are unaged and have higher moisture content.
The cheese industry employs over 130,000 people in the United States alone.
Cheese wheels were once rolled down Cooper's Hill in England during an annual racing competition.
Lactose-intolerant individuals can often eat aged cheeses because the lactose breaks down during aging.
